title: Miniature Xmas Tree in Red and Green

description.text:
Mini Xmas tree suitable for dual extrusion. Includes OpenSCAD source and STL files. Suitable for turning into ear-rings  
UPDATE: Mk II versions added as I found the bond between the body and hanging ring was weak and easily broken. Hopefully fixed now.

Printed using red and green 1.75mm PLA on a Wanhao 4S.  Heated bed switched off and covered with 3mm glass plate with blue painters tape.  
Both nozzles set to 210 degC and exported from MakerWare.  Print time 15 minutes.  
The tree trunk is set into the base through a small printed pin but the hanging ring is only fastened to the top by simple plastic adhesion.  
I've uploaded separate STL files for red and green.  When imported into MakerWare they will line up in readiness for dualstrusion.  
The OpenSCAD model was a quick hack but the red green pieces can be identified as they're tagged with the correct colour. Commenting out the appropriate sections will enable you to export your own separate STL files if you desire.

The printable parts are a panel to house three ~1" diameter potentiometers, and a round knob to fit their 1/4" shaft. It was designed as a color mixer:
http://www.flickr.com/photos/miffyg/sets/72157625793863655/

For the color mixer I used high intensity R, G, and B LEDs, diffused with fine sandpaper. I soldered the components directly to each other for simplicity and structural support. My Arduino code is attached.

Ã‚Â° range from 0-1024. Size and feel were stronger deciding factors as the value gets mapped down to the LED range of 0-255 anyway.

comments.text: Thanks! I only buy new parts if absolutely necessary; I have plenty of single-color LEDs around. Plus this solution is brighter, a better-looking circuit, reveals more about the light being mixed, and casts three shadows.

title: Alarmclock with an old Android Phone

description.text:
My old phone serves me as an alarm clock with this case instead of staying in the drawer.
A Desire HD fits almost perfect in this case. Modify the scad file for your phone. The screen stays on while charging when you follow this instructions
  • Open the settings
  • Click on About device
  • Click on Build number 7 times
  • Go back to settings screen and you will see Developer options. From here you can access the Stay Awake function.

author: schmiddim

description.text:
I have need for some common bar ends.
This thing forms a "clevis joint" I believe it is called.
The default size will allow you to slip an 8mm rod/dowel inside.  The hole for the pin will fit an M3, or 3mm plastic filament probably.  Good enough for prototyping.  Printing on its side would probably be best for structural strength.

1) Figure out where you might need a Clevis joint in your design
2) Print a few of these out
3) Stick a rod of some sort into the end
4) Put a mating part into the rounded end
5) Place a 'pin' in the hole
6) Rejoice!

The file membrane = two halves of the model - print , glue to halves and please share the result...
You can use the file "polygon divided" for a more smoother result This model includes:

  • symporter/antiporter protein embedded in the membrane

description.text:
One thing that often frustrates me both as a GM and a player about mounted combat: it can happen both while you're mounted and when you're unmounted.  If you use miniatures, this means either you need separate minis for being mounted and not, or you need some (usually wonky) solution to represent mounted minis.  
This is my less-wonky solution.  The warhorse is on a 2"x2" square (appropriate for a Size-Large creature's space) and has a 2"x1" "saddle" elevated to remind you the rider is on higher ground.  Usually only one character rides a given horse, but sometimes things don't go that way, so the saddle holds two.  
NOTE: the images of the warhorse come from the intarwebs and I don't know what (if any) licensing is granted.  I'll post references once I can figure out what the right way to do this is.

• cut it from 1/8" plywood or plastic
  • clean it up before you glue it
  • OPTIONAL: paint it. I don't, but I like the look of the wood I used to cut it with-- if you use scrap, you may prefer to paint it.
  • glue it together
  • play :-)

title: CraftBot build plate nut mod [Flex filament]

description.text: The CraftBot is an excellent piece of hardware. One of the few weak points in the design is the stiff yet flimsy little nylon nut used to hold the build plate in place. I lost a large print once when the vibrations made the nuts come loose, and the plate actually fell out of the machine during the print. This modification consists of a larger knob printed in flex material, with the old nut inside. It holds the plate with a firmer grip. Edit: Also see http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:609874 which is a bit slimmer and takes a metal M4 nut.
Print in flexible material, stick the old nut inside and attach under the build plate.

author: Marrrs

description.text: It is cool!!!!!

Set your Z home position using a micrometer head instead of fiddling around with a hard to get to machine screw.  Inspired by an original design by Plexus on printerbottalk.com who deserves credit for the idea.  Should work on a printrbot LC, but not tested.

Get a micrometer head.  I found a good deal on a 0-13mm one on the favorite auction site, but 0-25 should work too.
Obtain a length of 6-32, M3.5, or similar threaded rod.  You'll need somewhere around 8 to 10cm, depending on your micrometer head.
A locknut, or pair of nuts, to fit
A compression spring that fits around the thread, extended length about 40mm.  Not critical and not very strong , it's to hold the althread against the head - I got one off the display at my local hardware store.
Measure the diameter of the collar on your mic and adjust the OpenSCAD file if necessary.  Print the holder - I used blue repraper PLA, 0.2mm layers, 100% infill every 2 layers.  An additional part is included to go on the top end of the allthread and over the shaft on the head - tap the small hole to fit your allthread.  I never used it.
Remove the original 6-32 Z adjuster screw and make sure the holder fits - the bottom tab should rest on the original plywood piece, the top should hook over the left (X0) side of the bridge.  Recalibrate and reprint, or file to fit, as necessary.  The small holes should line up with the original screw hole, too.
Clean up the holes for the micrometer head and allthread, if necessary.  There's a horizontal hole in the top of the bracket (points to the right) for a M3 SHCS.  Mine was close enough to self tap, but run a tap through it if you need to.  Install the micrometer head, point the scale towards the hook on the top bracket, and gently lock it in place with the SHCS.
Put the allthread through the bottom hole, put the spring between the two tabs and compress it enough to get the locknut on, screw on the locknut (might require an extra hand or some strong language).  Adjust the micrometer to zero, then screw the allthread up (or the nut down) until the spring is compressed a few mm after the allthread touches the micrometer.
Adjust the micrometer to about a third to half of it's travel, them measure how much screw thread is below the plywood tab on your current adjuster and add 6mm (the thickness of the plywood).  Cut off your allthread so this much is below the bottom tab.  If you're confident in your measurement use half the mic range first, if you think you're a bit long or short go up or down as appropriate.  You can always cut another piece...  File the end flat if necessary.
Prop your printerbot's bridge up, run up the Z, or remove, so you can get to the underside of the Z adjuster tab.  Enlarge the hole so your allthread will just slide freely- you did check it was in the right position in the step above, didn't you?  I used several drill bits in increasing sizes, turned by hand, and a bit of small round filing.  If the bridge was removed, Drill, baby, Drill.   If you change your mind and go back to a screw adjuster just epoxy a nut on the tab.
Put the gadget in place, sliding the althread through the original hole (printing off?  file some more).  Recheck that the hook goes over the top left of the bridge, and the bottom tab sits on the original adjuster.  File if needed.
Cable tie it in place, one small tie to hold the bottom tab to the original adjuster, one on the side as high as it'll go to hold it snug against the side.
Turn the knob to rehome.  Enjoy!

author: gordonendersby

description.text: Today was Fashion Hacking day with Diana Eng at NYC Resistor and I've wanted to make these keyboard pants for a long time. The basic idea was to take a flexible silicone keyboard and somehow integrate it with some pants (or shorts). I had they keyboards laying around for a while and I ran down to the Conways to get some jeans for about $8 (Yay fulton mall!) This was inspired by a cool project I saw a long time ago on the hypernets: http://www.engadget.com/2008/04/23/keyboard-infused-pants-make-it-okay-to-grab-your-crotch/

Now, the question was how do I attach the keyboard to the pants? Well, the first step was to cut the keyboard in half. I could've tried to put it somewhere different, but I wanted it to be in a place where it was convenient to type... which is right in the middle of your thighs. Once I had cut them in half, I inspected the circuit to see just how hard it would be to solder the traces back together. Unfortunately it was impossible to solder traces on, and it was equally hard to use conductive thread to join the traces. After a bit of fussing, I abandoned the idea of having a fully functional keyboard and just went for style points. Interestingly enough, the left side of the keyboard still works (its attached to the USB cord still) My basic process for making these was simple:
  • Scan the keyboards in on a desktop scanner.
  • Import the images into Inkscape and trace vectors around all the keys.
  • Open the SVG into Corel Draw for lasercutting. (power to 85, speed to 70)
  • Lasercut the jeans with a piece of wood between the layers so it only cut the front.
  • Sew around the edges of the keyboard to attach them to the jeans. The edges were just silicone which was really easy to sew through.
  • Sew a patch behind the keyboard so that its not silicone directly on your skin (gets a bit sweaty)
    • It was a fun afternoon build process, and I really enjoyed combining hacking and clothing (and fashion?). Sewing was actually pretty fun, but so is everything else that involves dangerous objects. I also really enjoyed the physical object -> digital design -> physical object from using the scanner as the initial data input. Oh, and even though the keyboard just barely functions, here's a video of me kicked back playing Tetris on them: http://blip.tv/file/2095987

description.text:
The clevis: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:5889
needs a mate. This thing, combined with a female clevis, will form a joint. Depending on what you attach the inserted bars to, very interesting degrees of freedom will ensue. This thing has a M3 hole in the position where a matching clevis can be joined. You can use an M3 bolt/nut combo, or make the hole any size you like and use more exotic fasteners. the most ideal situation would be to put tiny little ball bearings in there, and a nice precision pin as a joiner. But, using a simple 3mm piece of ABS filament will also do the trick and if you melt the end a bit, provide you with a quick fastener.

1) Excitedly look at your design for places where you can use a clevis joint
2) Print this thing, and the clevis female thing.
3) Line up the holes, and put a piece of ABS 3mm plastic in there.
or Use whatever fastener you like. Whatever your choice, it needs to be able to pivot around the hole, and it needs to hold the two pieces together.
4) Secure a shaft into the larger hole with glue, or whatever suits your material
5) Rejoice!

comments.text: The .stl should be for 5/16" but it's a slip on fit, not for 'threaded'.  Meaning, a 5/16" rod will slide in with wiggle room.  I don't know how much wiggle you're experiencing, perhaps you could post a picture?  While prototyping, I generally print them this way, and then wrap tape around the end of the rod to get the right thickness and do a friction fit.  That way I can easily pull them on and off, but they generally stay firmly enough while I'm playing around.

title: DJI F450 adapters for 0.5" X525 aluminium arms

description.text:
Warning!
If you are using the type of landing legs in the pictures (DJI landing skids), use all four screw holes! Depending on the frame, you may have to drill these holes. The landing legs will otherwise act as a lever when landing and eventually tear the adapters apart. This also happens on original DJI arms, but not as quickly, as they are injection molded.

Update 29.01.2015:
All versions updated. Designed my own rear part of it (no longer taken from another source), made it slightly lighter and easier to print. There will be a 1-2 layer thick ceiling in the opening at the back now. You can either leave it or cut it out, the main purpose is to avoid ABS curling on the arc. Print with brim if you still have issues. No support needed.

Update 23.01.2015:
Knurled version updated again with slightly larger holes.
If plastic rises into the screw hole of the knurled nut, use a 2mm metal drill to carefully drill out the hole again. Try not to touch the metal thread with it and dust off the drill bit regulary to allow it to transport the plastic. Update 18.01.2015:
All models updated. There is now a 1-2 layer thick cover on the inside 4mm hole. This will allow the printer to use bridging rather than sticking a hard-to-remove support into the square hole. So these will now print without support and end up with a cleaner inside surface. Stick a screwdriver in there and the layer will easily break apart to open up the hole. You still may have to file the square holes open a little depending on your printer calibration. Also added: "Knurl" version of the spare arm one. This one is meant to be used with metal inserts like these: http://www.ebay.com/itm/251716998095
Melt them into the four main holes with a soldering iron. The rear two holes don't have space for threaded inserts, as they only give some extra support anyways. Test flight was successful, the arm adapters work fine.

I bought a nice "alien" type frame that uses the DJI arms, but don't like the plastic arms for various reasons. So I created my own adapters to fit the X525 quadcopter frame arms (0.5"/13mm), based on the rear part of dirkdirks F550 arms. Not flight tested yet due to weather, but they feel very sturdy and hold the arm firmly.
The aluminium arm is replacable by just releasing one screw, if one is bent. "Spare" fits the clone arms (http://www.hobbyking.com/hobbyking/store/uh_viewItem.asp?idProduct=40663).
"Stock" should fit the original X525 arms which are slightly larger all around. This is currently untested, however. I printed them in ABS, 50% infill, with brim (to prevent the thinner loop part from lifting) and sliced with Slic3r. Support is needed around the M4 hole.
The screw holes are undersized on purpose, so a metal screw will cut its own thread. The end of the adapter will stick out from the center plates some, this is pretty much unavoidable to give the arm enough support. An M4 screw holds the arm in place. It'll be a bit of a tight fit, which only adds to the stability. Requirements per arm:
4x M3x10 screw (2x M3x10 and 2x M3x16 if you want to use the landing gear from DJI as pictured)
2x M3x12 scew
2x M3 lock nut
1x M4x35 screw (I originally used 30mm, but have to turn the lock nut around then)
1x M4 lock nut
2x M4 washer
6x M3 washer

description.text:
With the OpenSCAD file you can create you own calibration object the easy way.
Just enter the X and Y length, the wall height and the wall thickness into the OpenSCAD File like you want. One Example for calibration (that´s how i did it.. maybe not the right way ;-))
  • Open SCAD-File and enter the nozzle diamenter as wall thickness. Then compile and render and export as STL
  • With your Slicer Software (for example Kisslicer) set the extrusion width to your nozzle diameter (for example 0.35). Use as flow tweak 1.0
  • Print the object and measure the wall thickness (best at the last few layers, because the first layer was squeezed a bit more.. so it´s thicker then the rest)
  • Now calculate your Flow Tweakness by dividing set extrusion width with real width
    -> For example:
    extrusion width: 0.35 mm
    real measured widh: 0.25 mm
    = 0.35 mm / 0.25 mm = 1.4
    -> So enter as new Flow Tweak the factor 1.4
Made with OpenSCAD

comments.author: TutherJay

comments.text: Thanks!  I found the gear head is very sensitive to the spacing between the gears, a little too narrow and a lot of the motor torque is wasted pushing deep indentations into the filament.  Too far apart and you won't be able to use the motor torque effectively.  A 0.1mm difference in spacing makes a big difference.  Personally I like to have the gap tunes so when you try a cold extrude with PLA, the motor skips before the filament strips.  This way I feel like I'm using all the available torque and if there is more backpressure than the extruder can handle (e.g. bed leveled improperly), it's more likely to recover.  This will vary with the type of filament though and the other thing I'm tuning for is to have enough grip on 618 nylon to do a cold pull.

remixed_from.author: PocketBrain
remixed_from.title: Desktop stand for 5" LCD panel frame

description.text: This stand is designed to hold a small DC/DC converter to adjust the fan speed.  120mm fan makes a great desk top fan.  Got the fan grill from thing:377600

BOM:
  • Screws, Machine, 6-32, 2", Qty 6
  • Nuts, 6-32, Qty 8
  • Washers, #6, Qty 12
  • Screws, Wood, #4, 0.5", Qty 4
  • 12V at least 1A AC/DC Power Supply
  • DC/DC converter (http://www.amazon.com/RioRand-LM2596-Converter-1-23V-30V-Pcs-LM2596/dp/B008BHB4L8/ref=sr_1_3 )
  • 120mm fan (http://www.mpja.com/12VDC-4-11_16in-Square-X-1-1_2in-Japan-Servo-Box-Fan/productinfo/18222%20FN/)
  • Potentiometer, 10k, 1/4", single turn, with stop and On/Off Switch (Pulled from old FRS radio)
  • 24AWG Wire, about 1ft.
    • Desolder the potentiometer from the DC/DC converter. Solder short leads from the 1/4" pot to the DC/DC converter pot location. Ensure that the orientation of the wiring matches the pot that was removed. Solder one short lead onto the on/off switch of the pot. Tie strain relief not in lead from DC power supply Solder (+) lead from 12V dc power supply to the other potentiometer on/off switch post. Solder the other lead from the potentiometer to the DC/DC converter (+) input. Solder (-) lead from the 12V dc power supply to the DC/DC converter (-) input. Tie strain relief knot in wire from fan. Solder red lead from fan to the (+) output of the converter. The leads may be shortened but be sure they are long enough to reach the fan when installed on the adjustable arms. Solder black lead from fan to the (-) output of the converter. The yellow lead is unused. Thread potentiometer through hole in control box. Tighten nut onto cover. Do not overtighten Place DC/DC converter on pegs on the 3d printed base. Use soldering iron to carefully melt the top of the pegs to secure the converter into place. Install fan grill, fan and fan support plate using 4 screws and nuts. Install arms onto fan support plate using placing double washers between the each contact of the plastic and 1 washer at each end of the screw. Tighten nut onto screw until the tension properly supports the fan. Place another nut on the screw and tighten snug against first nut. This will secure the first nut in place. Mount the bottom arms to the base using the same process used to install on the fan support plate. Carefully run the wires so that they enter into the control box under the cutouts. Place box onto base and secure with the 4 wood screws from under the base of the fan.

This is a fun project that combines the laser cutter, 3D printer and basic electronics (not to mention the fun optical properties of acrylic). You can use the provided files to make your own round ornament or attach the rectangular end of the vector file to your own design and have fun! This was initially designed as a thank you gift for people who buy from Imagination Supply Co (http://imaginationsupply.co) over the holidays (see light bulb picture) but it is too much fun not to share.

This is sized for 5mm Acrylic Using the vector file template, cut the outline of the ornament (or just use the end piece and design your own outer design).
Inside the ornament, vector cut a second design without cutting all the way through (In my case, I have an Epilog Zing 50W and to cut through 5mm Acrylic I cut at 25% Speed, 100% Power... for the inner cut I set it at 70% Speed and 35% Power) The design that is not cut through will optically reflect the LED light and glow. The STL file gives you a simple bracket that snaps over the LED and 2032 Battery and has a hole for hanging or can be used to stand it up as a night light.

Gantry crane powered by 2 stepper motors. (some assembly required).

Gantry Crane.
Don’t expect to have this thing printed and made in a day.
Extra hardware you will need-
28BYJ-48 Stepper motors (x 2)
37 x 17 x 10 Ball bearing.
String.
The model is quite modular, so you can make it as tall as you like. (Main supports must be in multiples of 2, and crane arm in multiples of 3).
Every part will fit within a 200 x 200 print bed and printed without supports.
It was drawn using Autodesk Inventor, for some reason the parts come into my slicer at 1:10 scale.
To print the main tower, scale everything by 10 (in Slic3r).
Check the orientation of the parts after placement. (The main uprights should be printed on their back), and all of the disks rotated 90 degrees.
Use the same members (as the main support) to print the crane arm, but scale all parts by 5 (half the size of the main upright).
From the base assemble (8x) main uprights, use the angle brace and the horizontal brace or cross brace to secure it together.
For the pin joints I secured the members using plastic rivets. To do this –
  • Drill holes to 3mm.
  • Cut short lengths of (3mm) filament to suit (20 – 25mm).
  • Heat one end of filament with soldering iron so that it mushrooms.
  • Fit rivet in place, and trim with 3-4mm exposed.
  • Heat exposed end of filament to mushroom other end.
    I used the same method as above to secure the crane arm parts, but instead used 1mm styrene rod (from hobby shop). Alternately you could use gravity extruded filament and a 0.6 mm hole.
    I used an old bearing from the front wheel of my go-kart for the turntable. The outer bearing retainer is made as an interference fit so it should hold tightly enough. As a worst case it could be secured with adhesive (epoxy or super glue) to secure it in place.
    For the crane arm, start with the front wheel braces attached to the (smaller) main uprights and work back, once again using the angle brace the horizontal brace and the cross brace
    Eleven parts will have to be glued; Cable drum, half wheel (3*2pcs), and the hook, and the Bearing base ring (with the roller bearing in place).
    My adhesive of choice is “Plumbers priming fluid for PVC pipes”. It is quite aggressive, and flashes off quickly, leaving only a neat weld. (Hardware shops stock 250mL bottles relatively cheaply).
    The stepper motors were the only parts that I used screws to secure.
    The cable drum turns very slowly, so I may look at fitting an external gearbox to that. (Possible future update?)
    • Feel free to post suggestions and comments. Most importantly... have fun with it.

description.text: COFFEE CUP

A servo-operated Pan/Tilt mount suitable for a typical android phone. I have provided scad files if you want to change the parameters for a larger or smaller phone. The original idea for this project came from http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:302741 ... so this mount is also suitable for a small camera like a picam or a pixy if the camera mount part is modified. This servo mount is part of a project for an internet-of-things capable pan/tilt camera using these parts, an Android phone and a Raspberry Pi running Python scripts and a mosquito MQTT server. The project works but the code is pretty rough ... regardless the project code is at https://github.com/DarfieldChris/MinePi.

The .scad and .stl files for the 3D printed parts are in the directory branch '3DPrinter'. The parts were printed with an infill of .8 (80%) with good results. The pan/tilt arm uses two servo motors ... the initial prototype uses: 1x SG-5010 TowerPro servo
1x SM-S4303R (not sure of manufacturer)
These servos were used because they were available ... one of these servos is cpntinuous and one is not. I would go with non-continuous servos for both motors ... the SG-5010 is non-continuous so I would go with two of these servos (or similar) moving forward. There is code for controlling the servos from a raspberry pi at https://github.com/DarfieldChris/MinePi ... the code is tied-up with MQTT Server communication so may not be useful but it is a starting point ... I ran the servos directly off the GPIO pins of the RPi.

A very simple design for a classic key. I printed a few of these for a cabinet whose original keys were missing. They work well, although if too much force is applied (i.e due to rusty or not smooth-turning lock) it may break.  
Note: this is my first attempt at 3D design ever, and I'm not good at it. So probably there is a lot of room for improvement in this model.

It can be a lot more tricky to print that it seems. I had plenty of trouble printing it in the original position, but eventually it worked. Use a raft or a brim to improve the adherence to the bed and to provide a more stable foundation to print the handle, or print it upside down, but then support will be required.  
For the best strength, use 100% infill, and make sure that the gap surrounding the hole at the bottom is correctly infilled by your slicer (you might need to adjust the extrusion width for this).  
Finally, if you have heat issues, print two or three keys at the same time, so that each layer has enough time to cool down properly.

description.text: U-MAKE is a "Frisbee" like flying ring designed for accurate throwing. Small versions are very light so the wind can affect the flight. description.text: Mario Kart is a very competitive sport in my family, and it's time we had something serious to play for! Enter the Mario Kart Trophy. Now the winners can bask in glory... until the next marathon session. Choose how you want to use the trophy - print all parts (as listed in instructions) and combine with some toys of your favourite characters to rank the positions of friends and family, or leave off the ranked placings around the perimeter and use it as a clean and simple trophy (also less printing required). Either way, take your karting to the next level! You can read about my process designing and creating this design on my blog https://edditiveblog.wordpress.com/category/mario-kart-trophy/ Also note that the base part uploaded here only says 'Mario Kart Championship' so you aren't stuck with my last name!

You will need to print 1 of each part file, except for the following:
  • 'Vine Top Left' x 2
  • 'Vine Top Right' x 2
  • 'Vines Left' x 6
  • 'Vines Right' x 6
    • You will also need to cut a base and ring from 24mm thick timber - I used some 12mm Particle Board and glued 2 sheets together. You might also like to try different materials like acrylic or even 3D print your own design.
  • The base should be 119mm diameter.
  • The ring should have an inside diameter of 170mm, and an outside diameter of 250mm.
    • The placings that go around the outside, as well as the central leaf, require you to drill holes in the ring. Match the drill bits to the pieces once they are printed out. This allows you to glue them in place securely. I used Araldite to glue all the pieces together. The 'Base Plastic Simple Logo' has a screw hole to securely fix to the base piece of timber. You can also find the Mario Kart character toys on Ebay or in some toy stores.

The rudder servo on my RC Boat used to be glued with double sided tape and came off once.

  • Attach Servo with M3 screws
  • Glue holder to boat
  • Go outside and play

description.text: This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://tinkercad.com/things/j6XsrvxNeVo

I made this can using Tinkercad.  It is hollow on the inside with capabilities to "drink" from the can.  I ran the .stl through Meshmixer to  add internal supports before printing.  Supports can be removed after printing.  
I created this can as part of a collaboration with an elementary art teacher in my building for an art project.  We will make cans and students can create "pop art" using the pop cans.

This thing is designed to be a toy to shoot bamboo skewers. I am going to be adding springs on the inside for the trigger and string lock. I plan to make those springs out of cut and bent binder clips. I am going to make the string out of a strong piece of rubber or elastic. It is designed to be glued together.
This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://tinkercad.com/things/ev4F9hDTmLf

Here's a stereo that runs the audio signal through an Arduino and then distributes the signal to neoPixel strips in the columns. The two potentiometers allow for control of the audio gain into the Arduino and control of the Hue for color distribution on the neoPixel strips. Really cool to rock out in the dark! Here's a video of it in action:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=iV14Z0pzgw0&feature=youtu.be

Just finished the build and testing. Bill of materials coming soon. If you want to get started on this project, do Jeremy Blums tutorial 14, and then use the Op-Amp circuit you build from that with Chris Wilson's Arduino sketch. Printed parts require a minimum print volume of 170x170x170mm. All parts were printed with 3 perimeters and 25% rectilinear infill except handles and switch case which I printed solid. You can expect the large prints to run for at least 30 hours depending on your speeds, so make sure your 3D printer can handle the workload. Base is a 2x8x16" board painted black. Stereo attached to the with zip ties. Hole pattern drawing file to help drill holes (tight group of 4 holes is the back of stereo) Electrical Schematic is now posted. Sources:
Jeremy Blum - Tutorial 14 on Op-amp Circuits:
http://www.jeremyblum.com/2011/12/25/tutorial-14-for-arduino-holiday-lights-and-sounds/ Chris Wilson - NeoPixel VU Meter Arduino Code
www.youtube.com/watch?v=5bldFRHe6Qc

T-slot based case generator. You specify what size object you want it to surround and your material width and it makes a printable box with slots for you to use screws to put it together. The github version allows you to export a file you can cut with a laser.

• Open in Customizer
  • Specify your params - in MM
  • Export each face
  • Print and assemble! (or modify STLs to accommodate I/O holes)
    • First this customizer-enabled object was designed to be a library to be able to generate cubes with different types of attachment mechanism. The first pass was t-slot (I think that is the right term) but I hope to expand it to be more versatile. That said full files that power this as well as examples of more complex boxes to hold PCB-electronics are located on github here. https://github.com/hendricksonrw/savorywatt-thingiverse/tree/master/58944-case-maker The default settings will allow you to just pick the size of the internal object and it will have 3 t-slot points on each face (you will be able to change this through the anchor count). You can use the library to customize each face as well as adjust the offsets to build your own custom case bases. The customizer version is not able to punch holes for your specific enclosures though I'm hoping to expand the library with some standard I/O holes (USB, Power, HDMI). The main parameters you can customize with the customizer are below // The dimensions of the size of the object you want to have inside
    internal_x = 100;
    internal_y = 100;
    internal_z = 100; // How thick your material is to cut, or how thick of walls you want to print
    material_z = 4; // Measure whatever screws you want to use with whatever nuts and set it accordingly
    screw_outside_diameter = 3;
    screw_length = 12; nut_outside_diameter = 5.5;
    nut_height = 2.5; // Related to the anchors themselves
    // Anchor Count determines how many anchoring points there will be along a face
    anchor_count = 3;
    // Determines how wide the teeth are that will be pushed into the opposing face
    tooth_width = 3;
    // Determines where the nut will rest, based on a percentage
    channel_position =70; // [0:100] //Select what part you want to export - make your own build plates
    part = "assembled"; // [assembled:Assembled, bottom:Bottom, top:Top, west:West Wall, east:East Wall, north:North Wall, south:South Wall] Part - Select what part you want to get or see an assembled preview Edit - Update - How to use the library
    Based on some comments I've received I through social media I thought I would point out the biggest benefit of this library, being able to generate a face with parametric specifications for how many holes and how many 'anchors' you want. So this Thing is a use for the library itself, that abstracts so it works with customizer. It doesn't expose the more powerful parts of the library because the customizer doesn't handle arrays very well and I felt it would be too complex. Here is how you create a face using this library. North, East, South, West - 1 denotes exists
    anchors = [0,1,0,1]; A 1 is an anchor, a 0 is a harbor
    types = [1,1,1,1]; If your face has to mate to a smaller face (because all the faces on a box cannot be equal and still grip each other) then you can specify how much to subtract. So the harbors in the ASCI below would have a negative offest.

__|_| North, East, South, West sides
offsets = [offset, offset,offset, offset]; An offcenter actually moves the entire grid of harbors or anchors on the face.

||___
offcenters = [0,0,0,0]; generate_cube([east_x,east_y,main_z], true, anchors, types, offsets, offcenters);

title: Christmas Flower with Seperated Center Ball

description.text:
Use it as either an ornament on the tree or around the house. Join a bunch together to make a wreath. As promised, this is the rehashed version which has the ball separate, which can be inserted in the flower section so you may print in a different color. For example, ball in red and flower in a dark green, I have tested this with positive results and I hope others experiences the same. The ball stem sort of snapped into place so I would assume it will all pivot on how detailed the ball print is. If you print it, please let me know how it turned out.
If you rework it, please share your creations and make a mention of its origins. If you like what you see please feel free to leave a tip: http://modernwebsitesolutions.com/resources/tipjar.html﻿ Thanks

The ball needs to be printed very slowly on low heat to try and keep the stem as cool as possible in order to prevent warping. A cooling fan on the print would probably work great to help this as well.

This is a multipart 50mm fan mount for use on the OrdBot Hadron X carriage. I have include the source OpenScad file and it is mostly parametric. Adjust it to suit your own extruder. This was printed on my own Hadron printer in PLA and it fit the x carriage perfectly. In this picture is the Makergear plastruder stepper motor with gear reduction unit. [Feb 2, 2015]
Hadron OrdBot users, be sure to check out my new 50mm cooling fan air-scoop add-on. http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:662787 It was designed to work with this fan mount and has been tested with the new B3 PICO hot end.

The source OpenScad file is included.  
There are variables in the source code which you may alter/change, however there are also variables which are not recommended that you alter/change.

Print Instructions:
  • Use the rotate option in your slicer/print software to rotate the extruder fan mount upside down for printing.
  • Infill: 20-35%
  • Layer height: 0.2mm
  • PLA filament

If the fan is too close to your build plate, decrease the mount_Z_depth (height) variable and this will raise the fan. If you do this, be sure to also change the fan_screw_height accordingly.  
The right side mounting arm connects to the main body with a bolt. This allows the mount to be adjustable.

A separate lower fan shroud to direct the air away from the tip of the hot end is ready. Go to my thing page http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:662787 to get the fan shroud built for this mount kit. Enjoy!

title: Tank Extruder Mount (RigidBot, E3Dv6, Printrbot Gear Head)

description.text:
Single extruder mount for a RigidBot. Uses the following parts:
RigidBot
E3Dv6
Printrbot Gear Head Beta
Gear Head Extruder Mount
2 - 50mm x 15mm radial fans*
4 - LM8UU Bearings
7W LED COB module* (optional)
4 - 70mm M4 socket cap screws
4 - M4 nuts (preferably nyloc)
4 - 16mm M3 socket cap screws (for the motor mount)
1 - 8mm M3 socket cap screws (for the motor mount)
2 - 25mm M3 socket cap screws (for the extruder mount)
2 - 4mm M3 socket cap screws (for the extruder PCB)
some 1.75mm NinjaFlex
assorted wiring and connectors *affiliate links Support:
Do not add support material inside the main air ducts, it will probably be difficult to remove. I printed with support material around the screw holes and near the radial fan mounts but it can be printed without (those areas are hidden anyway). Materials:
The flex top part was designed to be printed with a flexible filament, but can be printed in other materials {I'm currently using a rectangle of 3mm sobothane, but I don't think it makes a significant difference). The fan band should be printed in NinjaFlex or similar filament. I used PET+ for the main parts but I've also used PETG and PLA for some of the earlier versions. Warping from the heated bed or extruder may be an issue so ABS may be a better option if you can print it without warping. Assembly:
There are 1.75mm channels for NinjaFlex or other similarly flexible filament, 3 around each bearing and 4 around the heatsink mount (16 total). The 30mm fan band goes around the E3D fan, which slides into the slot between the two main pieces (see picture). I tend mount the fan backwards so the air and fumes blow away from me, but it may work better with fan blowing at the heatsink (facing the heatsink is the normal E3D configuration and puts less strain on the fan wires). The LED module slides in near the rear bearings. Wiring:
If you want to use both fans or the LED light, you'll need to make splitter cables or rewire the fans. Make sure the heater cartridge cables don't touch the air ducts or they may melt. Mounting:
Leave the M4 screws slightly loose until it's mounted on the 8mm rails, then tighten them gradually, checking that the entire assembly slides freely. It may require some fiddling to make sure the sides are parallel enough to avoid binding.

title: Thread Spool with Clamp for Sewing Machine
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
In our Hackerspace Chaostreff-Dortmund we have a Singer Professional XL-1000 automatic sewing-/stitching machine. We got some very big spools with high-quality thread, and even machine-lathed an adapter for them, but the tension on the thread was too high simple because of the mass of the big spools. The thread often cuts off and dozens of needles have been broken due to that so far. With the new spools no problem, no broken needles. I remixed a toy-spool for real use, so fame for the nice scad-file goes to the original part by user "creuzerm". The machine has a respooling-mechanism originally designed for the small under-thread-spools. The only disadvantage is, that you have to use your fingers to guide the thread while respooling because of the height of the spools. The spools should fit on any standard-sewing machine, but if it doesn't fit yours, you can customize them via scad or thingiverse-customizer. additionally I made a clamp to secure the spool when mounting the spool horizontal. you might not need this. The new spools are featherlight and work perfectly. Video of Spools in Action: YouTube-Link (Machine is printing a simplified Version of our Hackerspace-Logo, slowest speed setting machine can run on)
have fun and leave me a comment.
You might need agressive cooling due to hard overhangs on top.

author: gida38

description.text:
Are you tired of your micro crawler's horizontally challenged design? Do you frequently find yourself tumbling down your makeshift mountain of desk items? This upgrade might be for you! This chassis and drivetrain extension package will give you a better wheelbase. Its increased length also allows you to mount the battery lower in the frame, enhancing the center of gravity. More realistic bodies like those form plastic revell kits will also fit better.   
All hole placements were guesstimated, so I am open to suggestions for improvement. All ball link holes will need to be drilled out, though this is a fairly simple task.

Measurements estimated from a stock team losi 1/24 scale rock crawler (which I believe is no longer in production). It has been replaced with the 1/24 scale trail trekker, a near identical component design, but with an elongated truck frame.  
Measurements were made and then parts were printed.  
Holes drilled for screws that needed it
